Data cleaning

data_cleaning.Rmd

Preparing civil registration data for tabulation with the crvsreportpackage is a crucial step but there are several simple routines in R that can help make it less time consuming.

The tidyverse collection of packages contains a number of useful functions for cleaning data. In particular, the forcats package helps to manage factors and lubridate is handy when dealing with dates.

Let’s load the suite of packages.

library(tidyverse)

Then we’ll load the sample bth_data to practice with.

# import .csv file
bth_data <- read_csv("../inst/extdata/created_birth_data.csv")

# print the first 10 rows
slice(bth_data, 1:10)
#> # A tibble: 10 × 13
#>    birth1a    birth1b    birth1c birth1g         birth1h birth1i birth1j birth2a
#>    <date>     <date>     <chr>   <chr>           <chr>   <chr>     <dbl> <chr>  
#>  1 2018-06-10 2021-02-11 RegionA Twin            Midwife Other         1 male   
#>  2 2019-07-12 2021-03-19 RegionB Single          Other   Home         NA male   
#>  3 2022-06-16 2020-02-18 RegionD Triplet         Doctor  Clinic       NA male   
#>  4 2022-01-19 2022-05-14 RegionD Twin            Midwife Clinic        1 not st…
#>  5 2021-05-04 2018-04-09 RegionB Quadruplet or … Midwife Clinic       NA male   
#>  6 2018-09-02 2019-02-13 RegionC Twin            Other   Clinic        1 not st…
#>  7 2021-10-19 2022-12-10 RegionC Triplet         Midwife Other        NA female 
#>  8 2017-12-23 2018-12-21 RegionA Triplet         Nurse   Home          1 female 
#>  9 2017-04-18 2019-06-04 RegionA Twin            Doctor  Clinic       NA female 
#> 10 2020-09-07 2020-11-04 RegionA Single          Other   Home          1 male   
#> # ℹ 5 more variables: birth3a <date>, birth3b <dbl>, birth3c <chr>,
#> #   birth3l <chr>, birth3n <chr>

Factors

Show unique values in character variables

If you want to quickly scan all the known values of character variables in your dataset run:

map(select_if(bth_data, is.character), unique)
#> $birth1c
#> [1] "RegionA" "RegionB" "RegionD" "RegionC"
#> 
#> $birth1g
#> [1] "Twin"                 "Single"               "Triplet"             
#> [4] "Quadruplet or higher"
#> 
#> $birth1h
#> [1] "Midwife" "Other"   "Doctor"  "Nurse"  
#> 
#> $birth1i
#> [1] "Other"    "Home"     "Clinic"   "Hospital"
#> 
#> $birth2a
#> [1] "male"       "not stated" "female"    
#> 
#> $birth3c
#> [1] "Married"  "Divorced" "Single"   "Widowed" 
#> 
#> $birth3l
#> [1] "RegionC" "RegionD" "RegionA" "RegionB"
#> 
#> $birth3n
#> [1] "Urban" "Rural"

Convert character variable to a factor

It is common practice to read known values of a variable as characters, hence stringsAsFactors = FALSE. However, once you have read in the data you may wish to convert a character variable into a factor.

# check data type
class(bth_data$birth1g)
#> [1] "character"
# convert character variable to factor
bth_data$birth1g <- as_factor(bth_data$birth1g)
# check data type again
class(bth_data$birth1g)
#> [1] "factor"

Change order of levels

Sometimes the order of levels in a factor variable is not very helpful. The fct_relevel() function allows you to customise the order of levels.

# check the levels of the factor
bth_data$birth1g |> levels()
#> [1] "Twin"                 "Single"               "Triplet"             
#> [4] "Quadruplet or higher"
# manually change the order of levels
bth_data$birth1g |> fct_relevel("Single", "Twin", "Triplet", "Quadruplet or higher") |> levels()
#> [1] "Single"               "Twin"                 "Triplet"             
#> [4] "Quadruplet or higher"

Recode levels

Sometimes values of a variable are coded incorrectly. The fct_recode() function enables you to change factor levels by hand.

bth_data$birth3l <- as_factor(bth_data$birth3l)
bth_data$birth3l |>  levels()
#> [1] "RegionC" "RegionD" "RegionA" "RegionB"
bth_data$birth3l |>  fct_recode("Lagos" = "RegionA", "Kano" = "RegionB") %>% levels()
#> [1] "RegionC" "RegionD" "Lagos"   "Kano"

Dates

There are a few derived variables needed for the CRVS report tables that require handling dates. For example, we might need to derive the age of a mother from her date of birth.

Convert a date to a year 

year("1998-07-18")
#> [1] 1998

Convert string to a date 

dmy("18.07.2024")
#> [1] "2024-07-18"

Missing data

How we handle missing data is a key consideration: impute or drop values? But first we need to identify any missing values in the data.

Count number of missing values in each column 

bth_data |> map_dbl(~sum(is.na(.)))
#> birth1a birth1b birth1c birth1g birth1h birth1i birth1j birth2a birth3a birth3b 
#>       0       0       0       0       0       0      53       0       0       0 
#> birth3c birth3l birth3n 
#>       0       0       0

Convert selected string in single column to NA

We have identified no missing values in our dataset. However, if they were present you could adapt the code below to the variable.

bth_data |> mutate(col1 = na_if(col1, "Unknown"))

Geospatial

Simple point in polygon analysis can be useful to help identify which region a birth was registered in or whether a usual place of residence is urban or rural. To demonstrate we will load the states of Nigeria and identify which state the National Bureau of Statistics is located in.

First we load the necessary packages.

library(tidygeocoder) # for retrieving coordinates for a location
library(sf) # for handling spatial data

Then load the 36 states of Nigeria using vector boundary data supplied by Natural Earth.

states <- read_sf("data/nigeria.geojson")

Note that you can also retrieve the state boundaries of Nigeria (and any country) using the rnaturalearth package.

states <- ne_states(country = "nigeria", returnclass = "sf")

Then we will retrieve the coordinates (lat,lon) of the NBS head office using the geo() function from the geocoder package. We’ll then convert it into an sf object.

nbs <- geo("1 Wole Olanipekun St, Abuja, Nigeria", method = "arcgis", full_results = FALSE) |> 
  st_as_sf(crs = 4326, coords = c("long", "lat"))

Load nbs

#> Simple feature collection with 1 feature and 1 field
#> Geometry type: POINT
#> Dimension:     XY
#> Bounding box:  xmin: 7.500645 ymin: 9.061458 xmax: 7.500645 ymax: 9.061458
#> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
#> # A tibble: 1 × 2
#>   address                                         geometry
#> * <chr>                                        <POINT [°]>
#> 1 1 Wole Olanipekun St, Abuja, Nigeria (7.500645 9.061458)

Next, we’ll plot the results.

plot(states$geometry)
plot(nbs$geometry, add = T, col = "red", pch = 16)

Finally, we can use the st_intersection() function from the sf package to identify the state the NBS sits within.

st_intersection(nbs, states) |> 
  st_drop_geometry() # convert the results into a dataframe
